title: Study on human resource management in Korea'schaebolenterprise: a case study of Samsung Electronics
abstract: Korean chaebol firms have taken advantage of the ownerâ€“management system and to date are still enjoying its strength. I discuss the characteristics of human resources management (HRM) systems in the context of Samsung Electronics, Korea's largest chaebol following the Asian crisis of 1997, explaining why the SEC HRM system should be changed and what recent changes have been made, as perceived by both respondents and HR manager interviewees. The study of SEC HRM practices can provide real value to Western companies because it incorporates firm-specific advantages such as network strength, emperor-like power over group-wide management, and an agile decision-making process.

motivations: There is a need to understand and adapt human resource management (HRM) systems within Korea's chaebol enterprises, particularly in response to changing economic conditions.
Western companies can benefit from studying the unique HRM practices of successful chaebol firms like Samsung Electronics.
objectives: Analyze the characteristics of the HRM system within Samsung Electronics, Korea's largest chaebol enterprise.
Explain the necessity for changes in the HRM system and identify recent changes as perceived by respondents and HR managers.
methods: Conduct a case study of Samsung Electronics' HRM practices.
Gather insights through interviews with HR managers and respondents.
results: Provide valuable insights into firm-specific HRM advantages, such as network strength and agile decision-making processes.
Offer recommendations for adapting HRM systems in response to changing economic conditions.

motivations: There is a need to understand the characteristics and effectiveness of human resources management (HRM) systems in Korean chaebol firms, particularly in the context of Samsung Electronics.
The Asian crisis of 1997 has likely influenced the HRM practices of chaebol firms, necessitating an examination of any changes and their implications.
objectives: Examine the characteristics of the HRM system in Samsung Electronics, Korea's largest chaebol, in the aftermath of the 1997 Asian crisis.
Identify the reasons for changes in the HRM system of Samsung Electronics and the nature of these changes, as perceived by respondents and HR manager interviewees.
Explore how the study of Samsung Electronics' HRM practices can provide value to Western companies.
methods: Conduct a case study on Samsung Electronics to understand the characteristics and changes in its HRM system.
Collect perceptions from respondents and HR manager interviewees about the changes in the HRM system.
results: Provide insights into the HRM practices of Samsung Electronics, including the reasons for changes and the nature of these changes.
Offer valuable lessons to Western companies from the HRM practices of Samsung Electronics, particularly in terms of firm-specific advantages.
openai_json.research_subject: Human resource management in Korea's chaebol enterprises: A case study of Samsung Electronics

motivations: Korean chaebol firms have unique owner-management systems that impact their human resource management practices, requiring examination of their effectiveness and evolution.
The Asian financial crisis of 1997 created pressures for organizational change in Korean conglomerates, necessitating analysis of HRM system adaptations.
objectives: Examine the characteristics and recent changes in Samsung Electronics' human resource management system following the 1997 Asian financial crisis.
Identify firm-specific advantages in chaebol HRM practices that could provide value to Western companies.
methods: Conduct a case study analysis of Samsung Electronics' HRM practices.
Interview HR managers and collect respondent perceptions to understand HRM system changes and characteristics.
results: Samsung Electronics' HRM system demonstrates firm-specific advantages including network strength, centralized management power, and agile decision-making processes.
The study provides insights into chaebol HRM practices that can offer real value to Western companies seeking to understand alternative management approaches.
